comments.commentBody: To show their solidarity with the affected Americans, and to reduce the Federal deficit, the Congress should reduce the pay and allowances due Federal elected officials by one per cent of from the amount paid in the previous year when Federal expenditures exceeded Federal income in the previous year.
My stimulus proposal; Zero corporate tax for any business doing less than $5 million dollars in yearly revenue.

I do not believe that any commission that cannot be challenged re its plans for spending should be established.  One of the entitlement programs that presumably might be cut is Social Security.  The Social Security Trust Fund is being used to fund other items in the budget; that is why there are concerns about the future funding of Social Security.  Most people who get Social Security receive a relatively small amount of money.  Perhaps some people don't realize that some Social Security benefits (on the high end) are taxed. I am receiving a very miniscule amount of Social Security because most of my jobs were in the public schools and we were not part of the Social Security System.  My credits come from other, earlier jobs. Instead, we paid into a pension system. Those of us who have what is considered a higher income (and it is less than $250,00) are being asked to pay more for Medicare than the rest of the population.  Since I can afford to pay the surtax, I do not mind.  However, the general population of the U.S. should know that this is happening already.  I believe that we should cut back on unnecessary weapons and non-productive programs, not on job-creating or life-sustaining programs. During the Great Depression, it took spending to begin to create jobs.  It would be better to spend to create jobs, than to spend on unemployment insurance.  Thomas Friedman of the NY Times suggested yesterday that we have an entrepreneur program to create small and creative businesses.  This sounds like an excellent idea. Instead of all the name calling and bitterness, let's bombard the President with ideas and pledges of help.

Pouring billions into Wall St, banks, and Detroit was about equal to re-arranging the deck chairs on the Titanic. Sure, it looks all pretty at first, but when the reality sets in that once again we are back in the same mess as before, the ugly truth begins to show through. Taxes? What is left to Tax? Air? The american people have been taxed up the wazoo and when government spends us into the poor house WE have to foot the bill.

I said it before and I'll say it again. The best way gov't could have fixed the problem would have been to give every american a form where they list thier debts. at the bottom draw a line and this is what you owe. Give JQ Public a check with the understanding that all debts will be zeroed on or before 60 days from the issue of the check. While the gov't is still holding massive amounts of debt, corporate america would be paid off, businesses would have money again, and jobs would come back. All we are doing with the money now is giving 6 figure bonuses to the same knuckle heads that made the mess in the first place.

From the very beginning of the Afghanistan War, I've thought the U.S. was soft on the taliban but could never figure out why.  When the bombing of Kabul started, I remember listening to BBC reporters describe how the Taliban drove ou of the city every night before the US bombing and then returned the next day.  When we had them trapet at Bora Bora, we let them get away (I have a copy of that Time Magazine issue with the lonely Taliban on the hillside asking if this was the end).  It wasn't until I saw Mike Moore's 911 with the scenes of the Taliban visiting Dallas to make oil deals w/U.S. oil companies that it made sense.  I guess the U.S. still thinks it can deal with it's former CIA clients and get that those deals and pipelines done. But wasn't this the same Taliban that reniged on deals with the Pakistan government last year that set off the Pakistan Armmy offensive on them and the Pashtuns?

yoga is well on its way to just another intolerable religion.
so many people i know ( i live in LA ) that "practice" yoga are as just so self-righteous, full or them selves and annoying.
really no different than any other believer trying to show you the way or path as they would say.
sorry to say it yogi folks but your doing the world any good with your narrow minded ways.

This is hilarious.
Well-written.

Do we really want to carry this 'war' for decades more?  How many more of our young men and women need to die..and for what? Tell me why are we there?  Our military would never suggest an 'olive branch' as one poster said..they are military..fighting battles is what they do until the last man is dead. They don't ask why? They just do as they're told. And this government is betraying them with this pointless war.  We must get out..the Russians did .. and who blames them? We can give them humanitarian aid..if they want it ..but, with no education..it is a losing battle.  Please bring our guys and girls home Mr. Obama.. I promise I will never say a bad word about you again!!!!

The deal is simple.

Make nice long enough we can pull out our troops while saving face and you can have the country. Don't allow training camps for terrorists and we won't come back.

The Taliban will only keep their end of the bargain as long as it is in their favor to do so, but who cares. They want us out. We want us out. It shouldn't be that hard. The only negotiating point is not to let training camps be set up again, and if they do we should just bomb them. No troops, just air strikes.

We never should have stayed after removing the Taliban from power. Our interests should have been clean and simple. You harbor terrorists we remove you from power. The mistakes BUSH and CHENEY made were staying in Afghanistan and opening up an unnecessary war in Iraq. Well, that and destroying the economy, bailing out the banks with NO strings, cutting education funding, failing to invest in infrastructure, creating tax loopholes that favor moving jobs overseas...

I'm not a fan of the burka/niqab myself, but I just wonder, what would the response be if a woman wore the regular headscarf/hijab that does not cover the face and that many muslim women wear, and wore on top of that a surgical mask (a la H1N1). Would that also be considered prohibited?  It more or less covers the same as the burka/niqab, right?

We need to get the military out of overseas occupations and make the USA a hard target to save money and create jobs. The military industrial complex has been wagging the dog for too long.
Republicans will sit in protest rather than make any progress like good citizens. They are for the wealthy and worthless to all others.

I can't say I'm surprised that the Democrats are fumbling this. Meanwhile, health care costs continue to spiral out of control, millions are uninsured, millions more fall into medical bankruptcy. To the Republicans this status quo is all fine and dandy.

What's infuriating is that other nations have solved this problem. The outlines of a solution are clear. But the GOP obstructed as a political ploy, literally playing games with peoples' lives and health, while the Democrats dithered, as per their usual M.O. And now the GOP has its 41-seat majority in the Senate.

To me the public option has nothing to do with taxes. It means a highly regulated end to end health care industry so that no single player such as doctors, hospitals, insurance companies or drug manufacturers, (in my view the whole industry is a monopoly), can charge too much for anything and health care then becomes available and affordable to the person on the street. There will of course be alot of grumpy doctors but it will be no worse than it currently is. The government is not taxing anything. Just mandating what can be charged for what. So a government imposed price squeeze will force everyone down the line to cut prices and they will also be mandated to see people. So alot of "appointments" will be converted to walk in services and the current inefficient doctor office visits will out of necessity have to increase their efficiency. It you doubt it will work, just go to Japan. Works great there. So companies will still provide private insurance, but when people do fall through the cracks, the government guaranteed insurance will be there as a backstop to catch people. Nothing the government is going to do though without strict price controls from 1 end to the other is going to work out.

It's time fot Obama to dump the Frankenstein Monster of a health care bill that the Congress put together.  He should take the Massachusetts Bill, make the changes that they feel are needed after their years of experience with it, and convert it to the federal bill.  In the Senate he would have to get the vote of Brown who voted for it in MA. and says he still supports it. Other Repubs would be hard pressed to explain why they don't vote for a bill that was bipartisan (Repub Gov, Demo legislature), doesn't have the special interest deals they complained about with the prior bill, and doesn't contain any horror allegations (like Death Panels, Medicare cuts,...).  It culd be done quickly and would show they were responding to people's complaints.  It would show Obama is taking charge and leadership of the Party.

The Jets have a great core of young players. A corner who could cover next to Revis would help. Someone who won't get hurt for 8 games a season at nose tackle. A wide receiver who catches a bit more the Edwards. The rest is in place to become the darlings of the AFC East.

Two concerns about the Jets - 1) I believe in an uncapped year the top 8 teams can't sign free agents, so the only way the Jets can improve is via draft or trade. Now I might be wrong about this, but I believe that is the case. 2) If the Jets are the "same old Jets" then they will finish third in the division, Sanchez takes a step back, and the built up expectations of the Jets fan base is again crushed. The second concern is a bit more based on nothing but the mystic powers against the Jets, but this team at least looks like it might be different... Let's hope.
Like Wags, I didn't realize that the states' themes also were anagrams...very clever and fun...Coincidence...Rye following Paula G's puzzle yesterday?
I agree that (if I was a betting man) I like the Colts and I'll lay the points.  The Colts have yet to lose a game where they were starting their 1st team.  That's kinda scary.
AMAZING to me that favre makes mistakes that, for example, sanchez would be pilloried for for making rookie decisions.....

comments.userLocation: In the castle of my skin
comments.commentBody:
Most of the people commenting on the PSL issue are sadly out of touch with reality. It's easy for us to sit behind our computer screens in ignorance and shout "greedy" at the notion of PSls... but unfortunately this is the price of doing business in the NFL today. This isn't 1986 or 1990, this isn't even 1991 with "Plan B" free agency. Outright free agency has driven up player salaries (and rightly so) and those costs have to be met somehow.

It's nice hearing all the nostalgic stories from back in the day when a game ticket cost $5 and a hot dog 10cents, but Johnny U. maxed out at about $75k a year (I believe) so those memories belong somewhere etched in sepia... they really have no bearing on the economics of today. As Giants fans we want the team to sign productive players... well productive players (unless you get lucky in the draft) come at a premium... IOUs don't cut it, and unlike the Yankees, the Maras don't print money.

Now I fully understand the sense of disconnect many are feeling, and can appreciate the sense of betrayal as well... but business is business. If the team can compete financially then pretty soon they'll stop being competitive on the field as well... then we'll all be complaining. As a fan, it pains me... but as a realist I recognize it for what it is and adjust my reach accordingly. I was on the Giants waitlist for 18 yrs before I got an email congratulating me that my name finally came up for tix. Of course that "opportunity" came with a $20,000 price tag... not counting the season tix themselves, so needless to say I didn't even bother respond. So it's not like I don't feel the some of the same pain as the critics here.

As odious as we may think them, PSLs are here to stay... salaries are only going to keep rising. TV contracts, gate receipts, merchandizing can only recoup but so much. Right here in the NFC East we have two of the most aggressive marketers of their teams in Dan Snyder and Jerry Jones. Their personnel decisions haven't always panned out, but take a look at their payroll and overall net worth... compare that to the Giants. We are middle top in terms of team value which means our pocketbook is smaller than our rivals. To be competitive you have to play by modern rules. Let the fat cats go freeze in the cold or sit in their skyboxes. Hopefully I'll still catch the occasional game or two in person, but other than that I've I know that I'm limited to rooting from the cozy confines of my couch... with much better sightlines, so I don't waste any energy slamming the team unnecesarily.
Of all places on the planet to go hiking!  Is common sense not taught at Berkeley?

Walking into Thikana immediately induces a feeling of having reached a place of welcome and calm. This is no ordinary bed and breakfast, its walls feature contemporary Indian art, the furniture is elegant and the rooms, which are located over 3 levels are comfortable, the bathrooms stylish. There is a wonderful terrace at the top where you can relax with a beer and take a detached look at the traffic and to the park beyond. I stayed with my daughter over 4 nights and we immediately felt at home not only because of the wonderful ambiance but mainly because we were welcomed by Atul and Sheetal personally. They make time to get to know each guest and then make sure that they and their staff look after their needs and answer all their questions. We were really sad to leave, and hope to get back one day. We would recommend Thikana to any travellers who wish to enjoy a sophisticated relaxing environment, enjoy good conversation with Atul and the other guests, and friendly service from the staff. It was a joy to meet them and stay there.

As i started reading this article, I was hoping for the best, but reality gripped my better conciousness. A union run kitchen in a hotel is doomed. Unskilled line cooks, petty union rules, and above all a professional chef who has accepted mediocrity. Unions have hired the immigrant over the skilled american. You deserve what you pay for....
Why do Americans have to combine eating with every possible activity?

Yoga has become so utterly pretentious and materialistic that it has lost its very soul. Talk about laying ruin to an age-old practice. It's like Walmart selling rows and rows of Buddha statues - god keep the west away from anything real, please.
How self-indulgent. Don't these people read the news?
